title: Managing ADHD with Apple and Siri
text:
Growing up in Silicon Valley, Apple was everywhere. After owning various Apple products for almost 14 years and experimenting with the ecosystem and its capabilities, I have learned a variety of strategies that help me manage my ADHD. Before diving into these, I would like to preface this post with the observation that having multiple Apple products is part of why I find Apple tools so helpful. iCloud makes syncing with my phone, watch, iPad, and laptop incredibly easy. When I set a reminder for a Calendar event, I will receive a notification not only on my phone, but also on my watch, iPad, and laptop. It’s okay if I don’t hear my phone remind me of an appointment because I can hear a notification from my watch and feel the notification on my wrist. If I don’t hear or feel my watch, then perhaps I’m hyperfocused on something on my iPad or laptop. Multiple devices receiving the same notification means there are backups if the alert from one device goes overlooked.
Three essential tools of the Apple ecosystem that I have used to great benefit are widgets, Siri, and Apple HomeKit.

title: Managing ADHD with Apple and Siri
text:
Apple Watch Complications
When I got my first Apple Watch, my primary watch face was Activity Digital. It was January 2021, and COVID-19 was rather conducive to a sedentary lifestyle. I like data and numbers, so the information tracked on my Apple Watch would help motivate me to get up and move. However, Activity Digital was soon superseded in favor of another watch face, Modular .
While attending UCSD, my calendar noted lectures, discussions, office hours, and even exams. Event alerts are useful, but there were simply too many events on my calendar. Modular allowed my to see my schedule at a glance, and tapping the complication opened my Calendar if I needed further information.

title: Managing ADHD with Apple and Siri
Managing ADHD with Apple and Siri

Managing ADHD with Apple and Siri
Managing ADHD with Apple and Siri
text:
Lights
I use smart (dimmer) switches or smart plugs so that I can ask Siri to turn on or turn off my lights. I set automations for turning my lights off in case I accidentally fall asleep before turning them off myself. Currently, the automations are set for every hour, on the hour. Since I also have difficulty noticing or feeling time passing, I find that the lights turning off every hour (even if I turn them back on again) helps me mark the passing of time.

title: Managing ADHD with Apple and Siri
text:
Other
I get very cold very easily, so I love using a space heater to make my room nice and toasty. Generally, I am especially mindful with heat-generating appliances and I double check that I have turned things off when I am done using them. Whereas I can only check again that I have turned off the stove when I am done cooking, the space heater is an easy opportunity for a smart-plug safeguard. I can set the plug to turn off when I leave home. With the space heater plugged into the smart plug, which is plugged into the outlet, the heater will turn off when I leave home even if I forgot to turn it off manually. title: Research
text:
I am currently researching affective polarization, civic duty, and voter turnout. The literature is inconclusive regarding a (clear) relationship between affective polarization and turnout. I theorize that civic duty may help explain the relationship by acting as a mediator.
My next research project will look at affective polarization, civic duty, (preference for) straight/split ticket voting, and vote choice.
My research interests include:

Affective polarization, also ideological and geographic polarization
Public opinion
Political behavior
State comparative politics
California politics




Climate Policies by State. Data from the State Climate Policy Dashboard (climatepolicydashboard.org).

title: Jillian Reynolds
text:
I am currently a second-year research master student in the Modern History and International Relations program at the University of Groningen in the Netherlands. A research master is a two-year, research-focused program for students interested in pursuing a PhD or career in research.

After graduating high school and completing the IB Diploma Programme, I attended UC San Diego in La Jolla, California. At UCSD, I majored in Political Science/International Relations and earned minors in History and Global Health.
After earning my BA in 2023, I spent a year working as a paraeducator for a local public school district while completing the four-course R for Data Analytics certificate program through UC San Diego Division of Extended Studies.
